text: I'm Eep. Of the Croods clan.
That's old Eep. I'm new Eep.
And new Eep just needs a pen.
so what put the new in new me?
I'm glad I asked myself that question.
I was walking with my family,
my dad Grug, my mom Ugga,
my little brother Thunk, my little sister Sandy,
as in my guy, the guy of my dreams but real.
So, of course, Dad smashed through it.
And there was a farm and a tree house.
And a family, the Bettermans, Phil, Hope and their daughter Dawn.
They weren't happy about their wall, and we didn't get along.
But then we were attacked by these crazy punch monkeys
so we had to team up to survive.
It went so well, the Bettermans invited us to move in,
And, boom, again, first best friend ever!
so welcome back, wall, and hello, peace and quiet.
Yep, the Croods are livin' easy now.
‐ No, honey, we just woke up.
The farm has food, shelter, and safety.
‐ Can we help with anything, Hope?
and you stay out of the way and do nothing.
We paint the things we do on rocks.
We gotta have a purpose on this farm.
Because, if we don't, we're as useless as a slugopotamus.
‐ Is doing nothing really so bad?
See? I've always said moving is overrated.
Oh, uh, could someone move my cup closer to my mouth?
‐ More time for careless whispers. Whoops.
‐ Wh... What about the sleep pile?
We did that every night in our old life.
‐ Fine. New Eep and Guy can cuddle with our eyes.
‐ Hey! Something to do just ran by.
‐ Let's grab it and stab it!
‐ Or, we can redirect that stabbing energy into something less stabby.
‐ Uh, I'm still waiting for someone to move my cup. Yeah.
‐ But we were gonna catch that pigator.
‐ No need. This trap is flawless.
Just like the rest of the system that runs this farm.
They're ripe. It's time to harvest them.
Bounceberries are a favorite fruit around here.
And they can be tricky. Even dangerous.
‐ Great! We love danger. We're in.
‐ You're out. It's taken care of.
‐ Uh, let me guess. By the system?
‐ Precisely. With me at the helm.
So, if you'll excuse me, I need to limber up before the harvest.
Time for a steam in the man cave.
There has to be something we can do around here
Guy‐Boy, I can hear those wheels turning.
‐ You get one pet name a day.
‐ Well, one idea is both sides compromise and live in peace.
‐ You just need something to do to be happy.
But it doesn't have to be work, right?
you find something and then you throw it?
Yeah. Throw might need some work.
we stop doing what Phil and Hope tell us to do
and we start doing what we wanna do.
Because this is our home now.
‐ Grug, go tell Phil that's what's happening.
‐ Yes. And I'll tell Hope I'm gonna help her.
Whether she likes it or not.
Her whole life, her parents have been so worried about her getting hurt,
they've never let her do anything.
‐ One pet name a day. That's two.
‐ You're always welcome in my man cave, Grug.
So I'm here to tell you‐‐
I'm here to tell you things‐‐
are going to change around here.
‐ Well, how long of a steam?
See? You're completely relaxed, thanks to the steam.
‐ So sweet of you to offer.
‐ Ohh. You wanna help make lunch?
So we share the kitchen, that was once mine. Good.
In the kitchen I helped build from nothing
that I never had to share with anyone before now?
How could I be upset? That's crazy.
Because that's all I eat. Meat.
‐ So you don't know what soup is.
‐ You're saying we're gonna do something around here?
But my parents don't want me doing anything.
‐ I'm so glad you guys like Throw.
Because we're not gonna do anything.
You're saying I could eat breakfast for dinner?
I could get dirty and stay dirty?
I could tell my parents what to do?
‐ Exactly. And that's just the start.
But I think your parents like to be in charge.
It's their thing. So maybe we start smaller.
‐ Well, what if we added something to Throw, like catching?
Ooh! We could call it Catch.
‐ Hey, uh, could one of you move my cup closer to my mouth?
‐ Or you could just get your cup.
It's all the way across the farm by my hammock.
‐ Or we go bigger. Bigger like a‐‐
‐ Which is what I used to say because I always served lunch.
But don't worry, I'll make a new lunch.
‐ At least they have something to do. Lucky.
We're gonna help you harvest them.
‐ And you will not... uh, stop me?
‐ Comin' in a little hot, Dawn.
I know nothing about bounceberries but they're my jam.
In fact, why don't you just make a to‐do leaf for us?
We'll all harvest the bounceberries together?
‐ You're heating up instead of cooling down, Dawn.
‐ I'm sorry, Croods, but we have a system here.
And, if you disrupt it, there could be chaos.
‐ I spent years creating an intricate system to run our farm.
Our food, our water, even our cooling breezes
are made possible by the system.
I said, don't touch the system.
For example, these vines gently gather chicken seal eggs
and carry them to baskets without cracking a single egg.
Which is why I said... don't touch it.
I've been looking all over the farm for you guys.
Hey, uh, could someone please move my cup closer to my‐‐
‐ If your system's so great, why did it break?
Guess we're better than your system.
When she goes after something, she gets it.
‐ Well, unlike your heart, I can't risk the bounceberry harvest.
So only the Bettermans can tame the bouncy beast.
We only do it because we have no choice.
And you almost die during every harvest.
‐ This year we have a choice.
The Croods wanna help, so let them.
Why stand in the way of the Croods' happiness?
Besides, what's the worst that could happen?
‐ Boy, those eggs were really up there, huh?
because the moment they leave the bush,
Eep, Guy, you run point and drive the berries forward.
Gran, Sandy, you're in the wings.
And you'll all herd the berries to this point here
so Ugga and I can catch them.
‐ What about me? What's my job?
‐ Oh, Dawn. This is too dangerous for you.
You could get bruised. Or bumped. Or tired.
You can watch from behind that rock.
‐ No. You can't make me watch my life anymore.
I‐I mean, if that's okay with you, Mom.
‐ Very well, let's do a trial run with a few bushes.
A dry bounce, if you will.
Rule number one, do not eat the bounceberries when harvesting them.
‐ Only if I'm bouncing with you, Eepykins.
‐ If you're enjoying it, you're doing it wrong.
‐ My dad was right. This is just like a kangadillo chase!
‐ Even better, everyone's cooperating and happy‐‐
‐ Your head looks like a bounceberry.
‐ Oh, no! Where are Mom and Dad?
‐ They're MIA! Sandy, break those berries.
‐ Oh, no! I think these bounceberries are going for a swim.
I told you not to eat them.
‐ Why not? We caught it. We eat it.
‐ That's why you can't eat them during the harvest.
The berry juice makes you sticky.
And when you're sticky, you can't harvest berries.
And I guess I get to do it again this year
on top of completely losing control of everything in my life!
‐ So, now that you're all too sticky to finish the harvest,
we have to find another solution so we don't have to do it.
‐ You think that's bad? I'm their daughter.
‐ Don't worry. I'll get us free.
Just need to use some muscle.
‐ Or we wait for them to come back.
‐ Hang tight! I'll kick you loose.
‐ Guy, get your face off my feet.
‐ It's okay, guys. Thunk'll save us.
‐ It's fine. Because we're going to pull ourselves apart on three.
‐ That didn't work. But it did bring us closer together.
So close, it's hard to imagine being apart from you.
We need to decide which one of us we're gonna eat first.
Ha‐ha! I knew you'd come back.
Didn't doubt it for a second.
You‐you can get us free, right?
‐ Of course. All it takes is water.
Why didn't you free us right away then?
‐ Free you? When the bounceberries are ready to be harvested?
‐ And priority number one is making sure we don't have to do it.
‐ Yes, as we recently established, I don't enjoy it.
But now it's in good hands.
‐ Why? Because punch monkeys do nothing but punch, steal, lie, destroy
and generally make our lives more difficult in every way?
They're strong, fast, they've got big hands,
So I asked them to give us a fist and they said yes.
‐ And now it's not. Isn't that great?
It was gonna save us from being useless.
‐ No, you're like a beautiful meteor shower.
‐ Comin' in a little hot, Guy. ‐ Okay.
‐ And you have a lot to learn about meteor showers.
Now, gawk as the punch monkeys do what you couldn't,
And for a mere one banana per monkey.
Huh. I don't understand that punch.
Uh, Guy, you speak better punch monkey than I do.
‐ He said you told them that they could take all the bananas they want.
‐ Oh. Thanks for clearing that up.
‐ They feel misled. So they're gonna take all our food.
Right after they trash the farm to teach you a little lesson
‐ They said all that with punches?
‐ So, Croods, you still want to help with the bounceberry harvest, yes?
‐ Oh, I wouldn't put it like that.
‐ And I'm all over it because this is how I roll now!
All Dawn, no rules, so deal with it!
‐ No offense, but your plan is why we need a new plan.
‐ So we brought you a bunch.
Look at us, working together, bouncing together.
Boy, I am really up here.
That one looks like a pillow.
And there's an egg, a coconut, Thunk,
‐ It's time to chew and shoo these monkeys outta here.
‐ And that's how you bounce punch monkeys out the door.
Except for that one. Which you are eating.
‐ The point is, we did it together.
We built a bridge between ourselves and we crossed it.
‐ No. The point is, we found our purpose here.
‐ Ooh. And afterwards maybe we could play Catch.
If they're busy, I get my kitchen back. So I win.
